unnormalised: Someone asked me about their experience with Emergency Med in India. I can share what happened with my grandfather last year. He suddenly clutched his chest at around 11 PM on 20/07/2023. We knew something was seriously wrong, he had a history of heart issues. Immediately, we called an ambulance. It took them approx. 25 mins to arrive, even though we live relatively close to Fortis Hospital. Those 25 minutes felt like an eternity.
normalised: Someone asked me about their experience with Emergency Med in India. I can share what happened with my grandfather last year. He suddenly clutched his chest at around eleven P-M on twentieth july two thousand and twenty three. We knew something was seriously wrong, he had a history of heart issues. Immediately, we called an ambulance. It took them approximately twenty five minutes to arrive, even though we live relatively close to Fortis Hospital. Those twenty five minutes felt like an eternity.

unnormalised: When the ambulance finally arrived, the paramedics quickly assessed him. They gave him some oxygen and started an ECG. They suspected a heart attack. I remember them saying "STEMI" but I didn't fully understand what it meant then. En route to the hospital, the paramedic kept relaying info to the ER, giving them the patient's vitals - BP of 160/100 and heart rate of 110 bpm - and preparing them for our arrival. It was chaotic, but the paramedics were so calm and reassuring.
normalised: When the ambulance finally arrived, the paramedics quickly assessed him. They gave him some oxygen and started an E-C-G. They suspected a heart attack. I remember them saying "S-T-E-M-I" but I didn't fully understand what it meant then. En route to the hospital, the paramedic kept relaying info to the E-R, giving them the patient's vitals - B-P of one hundred and sixty divided by one hundred and heart rate of one hundred and ten B-P-M - and preparing them for our arrival. It was chaotic, but the paramedics were so calm and reassuring.

unnormalised: At Fortis, Dr. Sharma and the team were ready. They rushed him into the cath lab and performed an angioplasty. Turns out he had a major blockage. The doctors said if we had delayed even by another 30 mins, the outcome could have been very different. My grandfather is now recovering well, thanks to the quick actions of everyone involved. That experience really showed me how critical and demanding emergency medicine is.
